posts.cooked: Hey, Mateo from 3324 here. Does anyone has CAD for an elevator (preferably thrifty or something similarly simple) that can reach L4? I can’t seem to get the dimensions right after a couple tries, and was looking for some help. I’ve already searched frcdesign.org , and couldn’t find anything. My current understanding is that we would have to have three stages, but that could be wrong! Thanks so much!

posts.name: Matthew K
posts.cooked: the TTB elevator CAD is on their product page, if you scroll down far enough. You can extend the box tube to reach L4 and should be able to still stay within starting config. I have seen Ri3D teams that used 2 stage elevators.

posts.name: Brett
posts.cooked: Im assuming you’re looking for a cascading elevator?

posts.name: John Bottenberg
posts.cooked:
The Greyt Elevator is back with a 4th iteration! Elevators can be used to lift objects high above the robot without extending reach and center of gravity outside the robot the way an arm does. It can also lift the robot as well!   Single...

Price: USD 299.99

This page has CAD links at the bottom. In Onshape, you would need to change the configuration to 3 stages - default is 1 stage. In order to change the height from 60 inches to something else (say you want 72 inches), you need to make a copy of the design and then modify the variable table.
yeah
Would you recommend using a two stage w/ carriage or a three stage w/ carriage?

posts.name: John Bottenberg
posts.cooked: It depends on design. My team is using that exact 3 stage elevator.
with the inside carriage on the third stage as well?

posts.name: John Bottenberg
posts.cooked:
I’m not sure what you mean by inside carriage on the third stage, but the elevator will look exactly like this: image 506×615 98.4 KB image 336×686 63.8 KB

image 506×615 98.4 KB

image 506×615 98.4 KB

image 336×686 63.8 KB

image 336×686 63.8 KB

posts.name: Matthew K
posts.cooked: The fixed outer bars do not count as a stage (as far as I know) as they aren’t moving, so the carriage is the 3rd stage in a 3 stage elevator.

posts.name: James Lyon
posts.cooked: The inside Carriage is what allows the elevator a full range of motion. If you for whatever reason did not what to use this, it would make it so whatever you mount on the elevator could not go lower than the maximum retracted Hight of the elevator (probably about 30in). This means you would need a separate mechanism to get the game piece up to that Hight.

posts.name: Chris Cross
posts.cooked:
If you want simple, a two-stage elevator will definitely get you high enough to reach L4, if designed correctly.  In this example, red is the fixed stage, blue is the 1st stage, and green is the second stage/carriage.  The starting height is 40" from the ground to the top of the elevator.  With the end effector at this height, you can drop a Coral on L1. image 480×509 19.3 KB

image 480×509 19.3 KB

image 480×509 19.3 KB

The elevator can extend up to 93" (with 5" - 6" overlap per stage), which is more than enough to get a Coral on L4. image 357×616 17.2 KB image 290×598 10.1 KB

image 357×616 17.2 KB

image 357×616 17.2 KB

image 290×598 10.1 KB

image 290×598 10.1 KB

There are a few advantages of a 2-stage elevator over a 3-stage elevator.  You save weight and it is less complex, easier to build and maintain. Hope this helps.

posts.name: Ege
posts.cooked: It’s a nice design, but how will you solve the balance problems caused by the elevator height?

posts.name: Sean Lavery
posts.cooked: Assuming the grey carriage moves within the green framework, this would typically be considered a 3-stage elevator in FRC terminology.

posts.name: Chris Cross
posts.cooked: Sorry.  In that example the grey part with the effector is fixed to the top of the second stage.  I should have mentioned that.  It could travel and become a third stage if desired.

posts.name: Ege
posts.cooked: I think you misunderstood my question. The system may topple over because it is high.

posts.name: Chris Cross
posts.cooked: This is true. A large, heavy base is an advantage here.  A light load up top and careful driving are also factors.  We ran a very tall elevator in 2018 (around 11’ IIRC) and had no trouble with tipping.

posts.name: James Lyon
posts.cooked:
Yes, this is something to keep in mind. You want the carriage to have as little wight moving up and down as possible. This is actually for two reasons. firstly, for stability, but also Due to the nature of cascade elevator rigging, each stage moves at twice the speed but half the torque of the last stage. this means its fast, but you have to be careful with what you place on the later stages (or just use really big motors).

Considering how little the elevator weighs, you will probably have some spare wight you can use a ballast.  as long as you are not flying around the field with the elevator extended, you should be fine.

posts.name: Matthew K
posts.cooked:
Lyinlyon:

If you for whatever reason did not what to use this, it would make it so whatever you mount on the elevator could not go lower than the maximum retracted Hight of the elevator

I could see some kind of high pivot arm put instead of a carriage (like many robots in 2023) be a good use for this. Otherwise, a carriage is essential for the range of motion
